sentence: Hello and welcome to the Rappaport Market comment.
I feel a bit bad about what I'm going to tell you.
When I was in Las Vegas for the JCK show three weeks ago, I took a few hours to walk around some luxury jewellers nearby.
I went into Tiffany, Cartier and Van Cleef & Arpels, claiming I was interested in viewing diamond engagement rings.
I'm already married, but I wanted to see first hand what the customer experience was like and how the sales associates spoke about diamonds.
They could probably tell from my  that I wasn't genuinely about to spend $30,000 on jewellery, and when they asked about my proposal plans, I dodged the question.
But still, if any of the salespeople are watching, I apologise for wasting your time or getting your hopes up.
What I asked in each store were a few standard questions.
Where are the diamonds from?
How do I know they're natural?
What styles are the most popular?
I'm going to summarise how it went, without naming the store, because I don't want to get anyone fired.
The first store I went to was very appealing, but I wasn't so impressed by the salesman.
He didn't seem very knowledgeable about diamonds and gemstones, he actually seemed like he read a Wikipedia article on them.
He conflated colour and clarity and didn't appear to know much about where manufacturing took place.
He said with confidence that the company had no Russian diamonds, but was shaky on the details.

To my surprise, he brought up the issue of synthetic diamonds right at the start of our conversation before I had asked about it, and was insistent accurately that the company didn't have any of them.
Yes, what matters is the ability to make a sale.
colours and clarities the company accepted and why.
When I asked about Origin, he cited the responsible jewellery council and his company's role in it.
This was an impressive performance.

The third store also had a knowledgeable sales associate who talked about the Kimberley process, said all the diamonds were from Africa, something I heard from a few salespeople, and was also very specific about what colours and clarities the jewellery accepted.
This guy rumbled me very quickly and asked if I was in Vegas for the show.
So here are my overall impressions.
There was a lot of diversity  in the quality of knowledge of sales associates.
There might be because different brands cater to different types of consumers.
There was a general focus on diamonds being broadly from Africa, without much mention of other locations.
To my recollection, only one of them said anything about Botswana, the world's biggest producer of diamonds by value.
There was also a tendency to rely on the GIA, rightly or wrongly, as the answer to all questions about product verification.
I'm not sure if the salespeople knew what the GIA did and didn't do, and  And I suspect one or two of them might have been overstating how much their companies use the GIA for origin confirmation.
in the comments of this video, and don't forget to subscribe to get notifications every time we make a new one.
Thanks for watching, and enjoy the rest of the week!
